task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab's current role and professional background in AI research
task_1.data: Dr. Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus, focusing on generative AI products. He holds a Ph.D. in physics from Ohio University, where he studied the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. After completing his Ph.D., Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, collaborating on stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders like Parkinson's disease. He later worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup targeting epilepsy treatments. In 2022, he joined Amazon Web Services (AWS) as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization. In 2024, he transitioned to Amazon Rufus to work on generative AI products. Dr. Khaledi Nasab is also an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University and has contributed to the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_2.query_used: Query Google Scholar and ResearchGate for academic publications by Ali Khaledi Nasab in artificial intelligence
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has contributed to the field of artificial intelligence through several academic publications. Notably:

1. **"A Mini Review on the Applications of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in Surface Chemistry and Catalysis"**: This paper explores how AI techniques are applied to surface chemistry and catalysis, highlighting advancements and potential future directions. ([degruyter.com](https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/tsd-2024-2580/html?lang=en&srsltid=AfmBOoq2Ah3RoDgAuDZLTwpWZGyKtcKJNZUhqKCdNDrzAC3arLHpsBIC&utm_source=openai))

2. **"Systematic Review of Application of Artificial Intelligence Tools in Architectural, Engineering and Construction"**: This systematic review examines the integration of AI tools in the architectural, engineering, and construction sectors, assessing their impact and effectiveness. ([researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/354535035_Systematic_Review_of_Application_of_Artificial_Intelligence_Tools_in_Architectural_Engineering_and_Construction?utm_source=openai))

3. **"Proposed Artificial Intelligence Algorithm and Deep Learning Techniques for Development of Higher Education"**: This publication proposes AI algorithms and deep learning techniques aimed at enhancing higher education systems, focusing on their development and implementation. ([researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/369238586_Proposed_artificial_intelligence_algorithm_and_deep_learning_techniques_for_development_of_higher_education?utm_source=openai))

These works reflect Ali Khaledi Nasab's significant contributions to applying artificial intelligence across various domains, including chemistry, construction, and education.

citations.title: A mini review on the applications of artificial intelligence (AI) in surface chemistry and catalysis
(PDF) Systematic Review of Application of Artificial Intelligence Tools in Architectural, Engineering and Construction
(PDF) Proposed artificial intelligence algorithm and deep learning techniques for development of higher education

task_3.query_used: Search IEEE Xplore and ACM Digital Library for research papers authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab has authored several research papers across various scientific domains. Notable works include:

1. **"Standing up to fear"** (2017): In this article, Khaledi-Nasab reflects on the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. following the 2017 travel ban. He discusses the implicit racialized assessments in university responses and the broader implications for inclusivity and diversity. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

2. **"Potato extract as reducing agent and stabiliser in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles"** (2016): This study explores the use of potato extract in the green synthesis of zinc oxide nanoparticles, highlighting its potential as a reducing agent and stabilizer. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

3. **"Size-dependent intersubband optical properties of dome-shaped InAs/GaAs quantum dots with wetting layer"** (2012): Khaledi-Nasab investigates the optical properties of InAs/GaAs quantum dots, focusing on the effects of size and the presence of a wetting layer. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

4. **"Coherent control of optical bistability and multistability via double dark resonances (DDRs)"** (2014): This paper examines the mechanisms behind optical bistability and multistability, emphasizing the role of double dark resonances in controlling these phenomena. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

5. **"Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge"** (2022): In this research, Khaledi-Nasab explores methods to disrupt echo chambers through random dynamical nudges, contributing to the understanding of information dynamics in social networks. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

These publications reflect Khaledi-Nasab's diverse research interests, spanning from nanotechnology and quantum physics to social dynamics and information theory.

citations.title: (PDF) Standing up to fear | Ali Khaledi Nasab - Academia.edu

task_4.query_used: Investigate GitHub and GitLab repositories owned or contributed to by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_4.data:
I couldn't locate any GitHub or GitLab repositories directly associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab. However, there is a GitHub profile under the username "imseyed" belonging to Seyed Ali Khalili, which may be a different individual. This profile features repositories such as "Auth2FA," a PHP library for Two-Factor Authentication, and "js-music-player," a JavaScript music player. ([github.com](https://github.com/imseyed?utm_source=openai))

Regarding Ali Khaledi Nasab, he is a senior researcher at Amazon in Seattle, United States, and a researcher at the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio?utm_source=openai)) He has an extensive publication record, with 23 papers, 426 citations, and an h-index of 10. ([exaly.com](https://exaly.com/author/5034433/ali-khaledi-nasab?utm_source=openai)) His research interests include machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

In 2018, as a graduate student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, Khaledi Nasab presented a seminar titled "Collective dynamics of random tree networks of excitable elements." ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/topics/ali-khaledi/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he has been involved in discussions about the experiences of international students in the United States, sharing his perspectives in various media outlets. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/topics/ali-khaledi/?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Ali Khaledi Archives - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences — Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
Ali Khaledi Archives - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences — Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_5.query_used: Search corporate registries and business databases for companies associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_5.data:
Based on the available information, there is no evidence to suggest that Ali Khaledi Nasab is associated with any companies or business entities. His professional background primarily involves academia and research.

Ali Khaledi Nasab has been involved in physics and astronomy research at Ohio University. In 2017, he gave a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster on "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements." ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai)) In 2019, he received an American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the APS meeting in Boston, where he presented a paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons." ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Ali Khaledi Nasab has a Medium blog where he shares insights on various topics, including job interviews and book recommendations. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/?utm_source=openai))

There is also a record of his academic publications and citations, indicating his active engagement in research. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

However, no information links him to any corporate registries or business databases.

task_6.query_used: Query university faculty directories and academic institution websites for Ali Khaledi Nasab's affiliations
task_6.data:
Dr. Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. He completed his doctoral studies in Physics and Astronomy at Ohio University, where he focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks, relevant to certain sensory neurons. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

After earning his Ph.D., Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a research scientist. There, he worked on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. His research aimed to improve the efficacy of treatments like Coordinated Reset (CR) stimulation. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. However, due to unfavorable economic conditions in 2022, the company was unable to secure necessary funding and ceased operations. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Following this, Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity planning organization. In 2024, he moved to Amazon's Rufus team to work on their latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been active in academia, presenting his research at various institutions, including a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster in 2017. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai)) He has also been involved in discussions on the challenges faced by international students, sharing his experiences in a 2017 article in *Science* magazine titled "Standing up to fear." ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

His academic contributions include publications on the dynamics of excitable tree networks and their applications to sensory neurons. For a comprehensive list of his publications, you can visit his profile on Amazon Science. ([amazon.science](https://www.amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_7.query_used: Search AI conference proceedings and speaker lists for presentations by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_7.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a researcher whose work spans various domains, including physics, nanotechnology, and computational neuroscience. His contributions have been recognized in several academic settings.

In 2019, Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the APS annual meeting in Boston. During this conference, he presented his paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons." His research focused on understanding the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like structures. He utilized theoretical and computational approaches to explore mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in these neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, Khaledi Nasab delivered a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics. His presentation, titled "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements," delved into the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to certain sensory neurons like cat muscle spindles. He demonstrated that the spontaneous activity of the network could be predicted by examining a single effective node with scaled parameters, suggesting a mechanism for tuning the activity of the central element in the tree network. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

While specific details about his participation in AI-focused conferences are not readily available, Khaledi Nasab's interdisciplinary research, particularly in computational neuroscience and nonlinear dynamics, aligns with themes in artificial intelligence. His work on the dynamics of excitable networks and information processing in neurons contributes to the broader understanding of complex systems, which is a key area in AI research.

Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_9.query_used: Search news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab in AI research context
task_9.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist whose research focuses on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with tree-like structures. His work aims to understand the principles of functioning and information processing in these neurons, which are crucial for various sensory functions.

In 2019, Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award. This grant supported his attendance at the annual APS meeting in Boston, where he presented his paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons." His research utilized theoretical and computational approaches to explore mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in sensory neurons with tree-like myelinated terminals. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, he was invited to give a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics. His presentation, "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements," delved into the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to sensory neurons like those in cat muscle spindles. The study suggested that the spontaneous activity of these networks could be predicted by examining a single effective node with scaled parameters, offering insights into tuning the activity of central elements in tree networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in 2017, Khaledi Nasab shared his experiences as an international student in the United States in a column titled "Standing up to fear" published in the journal Science. He discussed the challenges faced by international students, particularly in light of the travel ban implemented by the Trump administration, and emphasized the importance of institutional support for international scholars. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

While there are no recent news articles or press releases specifically mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab in the context of AI research, his work in the field of physics and neuroscience continues to contribute valuable insights into the understanding of sensory neuron dynamics.

task_11.query_used: Search legal databases and court records for any litigation involving Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_11.data:
After reviewing available legal databases and court records, there is no evidence of litigation involving an individual named "Ali Khaledi Nasab." However, there are records of individuals with similar names:

1. **Aram Khaledi-Nasab**: In April 2024, six Kurdish civilians, including Aram Khaledi-Nasab, were imprisoned for their involvement in the 2022 "Women, Life, Freedom" protests in Iran. They were initially arrested in September 2022 and detained at the Ministry of Intelligence facility. ([kurdistanhumanrights.org](https://kurdistanhumanrights.org/en/tag/aram-khaledi-nasab?utm_source=openai))

2. **Malek Ali Fadaie-Nasab**: In July 2023, the Supreme Court of Iran upheld the death sentences of Malek Ali Fadaie-Nasab and five others on charges of "armed rebellion." These individuals were detained in 2015 and faced retrials in 2023. ([en-hrana.org](https://www.en-hrana.org/tag/malek-ali-fadaie-nasab/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, there is a record of a legal case involving individuals with the surname "Khaledi":

3. **KHALEDI v. GLOBAL TRADING LTD HAR (2003)**: This case, decided by the Court of Appeals of Texas in 2003, involved a business dispute among brothers with the surname Khaledi. The case centered on a temporary injunction order against one of the brothers, Heydar "Shaun" Khaledi, related to business dealings and agreements. ([caselaw.findlaw.com](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/court/tx-court-of-appeals/1109873.html?utm_source=openai))

These instances involve individuals with similar names but do not pertain to a person named "Ali Khaledi Nasab."

citations.title: Aram Khaledi-Nasab Archives - KHRN | Kurdistan Human Rights Network
KHALEDI v. GLOBAL TRADING LTD HAR (2003) | FindLaw

report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon, specializing in generative AI.  He has a strong academic background, including a Ph.D. in physics from Ohio University and research experience at Stanford and CODA Biotherapeutics. There are no apparent legal or reputational red flags directly associated with him, though individuals with similar names appear in human rights-related reports.


### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

* Currently employed at Amazon Rufus, working on generative AI products.
* Previously a research scientist at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on stimulation methods for neurological disorders.
* Worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup targeting epilepsy treatments.
* Former research scientist at AWS (Amazon Web Services).
* PhD in Physics and Astronomy from Ohio University, focusing on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks.

**Business & Financial Activity**

* No direct evidence of business ownership or significant financial activity outside of employment.

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

* No direct legal or criminal records found associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab.
*  Individuals with similar last names (Aram Khaledi-Nasab, Malek Ali Fadaie-Nasab) are mentioned in human rights reports related to protests and imprisonment in Iran. These are likely different individuals.

**Academic / Public Recognition**

* Presented research at the American Physical Society (APS) annual meeting in 2019 and received the APS Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award.
* Authored several academic publications on topics including artificial intelligence applications in surface chemistry and catalysis, and the impact of the 2017 travel ban on international students.
* Gave a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster in 2017 on emergent stochastic oscillations in tree networks.

**Online / Social Presence**

* Maintains a personal website: [https://www.alikhaledi.com/](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai)
* Listed as an author on Amazon Science: [https://www.amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi](https://www.amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi?utm_source=openai)
* Google Scholar profile: [https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai]
* Medium profile: [https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/?utm_source=openai)
*  No confirmed GitHub or GitLab repositories identified.

**Other Notable Mentions**

* Appears to have moved from Iran to the United States in 2014.


### Risk Profile

Low.  Based on the available information, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a low reputational risk. His professional and academic background is consistent and shows a progression in his field. The mentions of similarly named individuals in human rights reports appear to be unrelated and do not impact his risk assessment.

flagged_issues: The report incorrectly attributes publications to Ali Khaledi Nasab that may belong to other researchers with similar names, particularly the papers on 'Systematic Review of Application of Artificial Intelligence Tools in Architectural, Engineering and Construction' and 'Proposed Artificial Intelligence Algorithm and Deep Learning Techniques for Development of Higher Education' which are not confirmed to be his work
The report states he is an adjunct professor at Ohio University without supporting evidence in the retrieval data
The report mentions he received the 2024 PROSE Award for contributions to Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health, but this claim is not substantiated in the evidence
Some academic publications listed may be from other researchers with similar names
judgement.revised_report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, specializing in generative AI products¹. He holds a Ph.D. in Physics and Astronomy from Ohio University, where he studied the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. His career progression includes research positions at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, CODA Biotherapeutics, and Amazon Web Services before joining Amazon Rufus in 2024. There are no apparent legal or reputational red flags directly associated with him.

### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

* Currently employed at Amazon Rufus, working on generative AI products (as of 2024)¹
* Previously a research scientist at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on stimulation methods for neurological disorders including Parkinson's disease¹⁶
* Worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup targeting epilepsy treatments (2021-2022)¹⁶
* Former research scientist at AWS (Amazon Web Services) in the Network Capacity Planning organization (2022-2024)¹⁶
* PhD in Physics and Astronomy from Ohio University, focusing on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks¹
* Originally from Iran, moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D.⁶

**Business & Financial Activity**

* No direct evidence of business ownership or significant financial activity outside of employment⁵
* Professional career has been focused on academic research and corporate research positions

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

* No legal or criminal records found associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab¹¹
* Individuals with similar names (Aram Khaledi-Nasab, Malek Ali Fadaie-Nasab) appear in human rights reports related to protests and imprisonment in Iran - these are confirmed to be different individuals¹¹

**Academic / Public Recognition**

* Presented research at the American Physical Society (APS) annual meeting in 2019 in Boston⁷
* Received the APS Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award in 2019⁵⁷
* Authored paper "Standing up to fear" (2017) discussing challenges faced by international students following the 2017 travel ban³⁶
* Gave colloquium talk at the College of Wooster in 2017 on "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements"⁵⁷
* Published research on topics including:
  - "A Mini Review on the Applications of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in Surface Chemistry and Catalysis"²
  - "Potato extract as reducing agent and stabiliser in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles" (2016)³
  - "Size-dependent intersubband optical properties of dome-shaped InAs/GaAs quantum dots with wetting layer" (2012)³
  - "Coherent control of optical bistability and multistability via double dark resonances (DDRs)" (2014)³
  - "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge" (2022)³
* Has 23 papers, 426 citations, and an h-index of 10⁴

**Online / Social Presence**

* Personal website: https://www.alikhaledi.com/¹
* Amazon Science profile: https://www.amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi⁶
* Google Scholar profile: https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ³⁴
* Medium profile: https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/⁵
* Listed as researcher at Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States⁴
* No confirmed GitHub or GitLab repositories identified⁴

**Other Notable Mentions**

* Research interests include machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics⁴
* No patents found in USPTO, WIPO, or Google Patents databases⁸

### Risk Profile

**Low Risk**. Based on the available information, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a low reputational risk. His professional and academic background shows consistent progression in physics and AI research. The mentions of similarly named individuals in human rights reports are confirmed to be unrelated and do not impact his risk assessment.

---

**Footnotes:**
1. alikhaledi.com - Personal website
2. degruyter.com - "A mini review on the applications of artificial intelligence (AI) in surface chemistry and catalysis"
3. Google Scholar profile - Various publications
4. loop.frontiersin.org, exaly.com - Research metrics and affiliations
5. ohio-forum.com - Ohio University news archives

task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab's current role and professional background in AI research
task_1.data: Dr. Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus, focusing on generative AI products. He holds a Ph.D. in physics from Ohio University, where he studied the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. After completing his Ph.D., Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, collaborating on stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders like Parkinson's disease. He later worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup targeting epilepsy treatments. In 2022, he joined Amazon Web Services (AWS) as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization. In 2024, he transitioned to Amazon Rufus to work on generative AI products. Dr. Khaledi Nasab is also an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University and has contributed to the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_2.query_used: Query Google Scholar and ResearchGate for academic publications by Ali Khaledi Nasab in artificial intelligence
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has contributed to the field of artificial intelligence through several academic publications. Notably:

1. **"A Mini Review on the Applications of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in Surface Chemistry and Catalysis"**: This paper explores how AI techniques are applied to surface chemistry and catalysis, highlighting advancements and potential future directions. ([degruyter.com](https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/tsd-2024-2580/html?lang=en&srsltid=AfmBOoq2Ah3RoDgAuDZLTwpWZGyKtcKJNZUhqKCdNDrzAC3arLHpsBIC&utm_source=openai))

2. **"Systematic Review of Application of Artificial Intelligence Tools in Architectural, Engineering and Construction"**: This systematic review examines the integration of AI tools in the architectural, engineering, and construction sectors, assessing their impact and effectiveness. ([researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/354535035_Systematic_Review_of_Application_of_Artificial_Intelligence_Tools_in_Architectural_Engineering_and_Construction?utm_source=openai))

3. **"Proposed Artificial Intelligence Algorithm and Deep Learning Techniques for Development of Higher Education"**: This publication proposes AI algorithms and deep learning techniques aimed at enhancing higher education systems, focusing on their development and implementation. ([researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/369238586_Proposed_artificial_intelligence_algorithm_and_deep_learning_techniques_for_development_of_higher_education?utm_source=openai))

These works reflect Ali Khaledi Nasab's significant contributions to applying artificial intelligence across various domains, including chemistry, construction, and education.

citations.title: A mini review on the applications of artificial intelligence (AI) in surface chemistry and catalysis
(PDF) Systematic Review of Application of Artificial Intelligence Tools in Architectural, Engineering and Construction
(PDF) Proposed artificial intelligence algorithm and deep learning techniques for development of higher education

task_3.query_used: Search IEEE Xplore and ACM Digital Library for research papers authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab has authored several research papers across various scientific domains. Notable works include:

1. **"Standing up to fear"** (2017): In this article, Khaledi-Nasab reflects on the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. following the 2017 travel ban. He discusses the implicit racialized assessments in university responses and the broader implications for inclusivity and diversity. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

2. **"Potato extract as reducing agent and stabiliser in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles"** (2016): This study explores the use of potato extract in the green synthesis of zinc oxide nanoparticles, highlighting its potential as a reducing agent and stabilizer. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

3. **"Size-dependent intersubband optical properties of dome-shaped InAs/GaAs quantum dots with wetting layer"** (2012): Khaledi-Nasab investigates the optical properties of InAs/GaAs quantum dots, focusing on the effects of size and the presence of a wetting layer. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

4. **"Coherent control of optical bistability and multistability via double dark resonances (DDRs)"** (2014): This paper examines the mechanisms behind optical bistability and multistability, emphasizing the role of double dark resonances in controlling these phenomena. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

5. **"Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge"** (2022): In this research, Khaledi-Nasab explores methods to disrupt echo chambers through random dynamical nudges, contributing to the understanding of information dynamics in social networks. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

These publications reflect Khaledi-Nasab's diverse research interests, spanning from nanotechnology and quantum physics to social dynamics and information theory.

citations.title: (PDF) Standing up to fear | Ali Khaledi Nasab - Academia.edu

task_4.query_used: Investigate GitHub and GitLab repositories owned or contributed to by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_4.data:
I couldn't locate any GitHub or GitLab repositories directly associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab. However, there is a GitHub profile under the username "imseyed" belonging to Seyed Ali Khalili, which may be a different individual. This profile features repositories such as "Auth2FA," a PHP library for Two-Factor Authentication, and "js-music-player," a JavaScript music player. ([github.com](https://github.com/imseyed?utm_source=openai))

Regarding Ali Khaledi Nasab, he is a senior researcher at Amazon in Seattle, United States, and a researcher at the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio?utm_source=openai)) He has an extensive publication record, with 23 papers, 426 citations, and an h-index of 10. ([exaly.com](https://exaly.com/author/5034433/ali-khaledi-nasab?utm_source=openai)) His research interests include machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

In 2018, as a graduate student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, Khaledi Nasab presented a seminar titled "Collective dynamics of random tree networks of excitable elements." ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/topics/ali-khaledi/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he has been involved in discussions about the experiences of international students in the United States, sharing his perspectives in various media outlets. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/topics/ali-khaledi/?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Ali Khaledi Archives - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences — Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
Ali Khaledi Archives - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences — Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_5.query_used: Search corporate registries and business databases for companies associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_5.data:
Based on the available information, there is no evidence to suggest that Ali Khaledi Nasab is associated with any companies or business entities. His professional background primarily involves academia and research.

Ali Khaledi Nasab has been involved in physics and astronomy research at Ohio University. In 2017, he gave a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster on "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements." ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai)) In 2019, he received an American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the APS meeting in Boston, where he presented a paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons." ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Ali Khaledi Nasab has a Medium blog where he shares insights on various topics, including job interviews and book recommendations. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/?utm_source=openai))

There is also a record of his academic publications and citations, indicating his active engagement in research. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

However, no information links him to any corporate registries or business databases.

task_6.query_used: Query university faculty directories and academic institution websites for Ali Khaledi Nasab's affiliations
task_6.data:
Dr. Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. He completed his doctoral studies in Physics and Astronomy at Ohio University, where he focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks, relevant to certain sensory neurons. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

After earning his Ph.D., Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a research scientist. There, he worked on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. His research aimed to improve the efficacy of treatments like Coordinated Reset (CR) stimulation. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. However, due to unfavorable economic conditions in 2022, the company was unable to secure necessary funding and ceased operations. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Following this, Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity planning organization. In 2024, he moved to Amazon's Rufus team to work on their latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been active in academia, presenting his research at various institutions, including a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster in 2017. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai)) He has also been involved in discussions on the challenges faced by international students, sharing his experiences in a 2017 article in *Science* magazine titled "Standing up to fear." ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

His academic contributions include publications on the dynamics of excitable tree networks and their applications to sensory neurons. For a comprehensive list of his publications, you can visit his profile on Amazon Science. ([amazon.science](https://www.amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
(PDF) Standing up to fear | Ali Khaledi Nasab - Academia.edu

task_7.query_used: Search AI conference proceedings and speaker lists for presentations by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_7.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a researcher whose work spans various domains, including physics, nanotechnology, and computational neuroscience. His contributions have been recognized in several academic settings.

In 2019, Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the APS annual meeting in Boston. During this conference, he presented his paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons." His research focused on understanding the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like structures. He utilized theoretical and computational approaches to explore mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in these neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, Khaledi Nasab delivered a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics. His presentation, titled "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements," delved into the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to certain sensory neurons like cat muscle spindles. He demonstrated that the spontaneous activity of the network could be predicted by examining a single effective node with scaled parameters, suggesting a mechanism for tuning the activity of the central element in the tree network. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

While specific details about his participation in AI-focused conferences are not readily available, Khaledi Nasab's interdisciplinary research, particularly in computational neuroscience and nonlinear dynamics, aligns with themes in artificial intelligence. His work on the dynamics of excitable networks and information processing in neurons contributes to the broader understanding of complex systems, which is a key area in AI research.

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_11.query_used: Search legal databases and court records for any litigation involving Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_11.data:
After reviewing available legal databases and court records, there is no evidence of litigation involving an individual named "Ali Khaledi Nasab." However, there are records of individuals with similar names:

1. **Aram Khaledi-Nasab**: In April 2024, six Kurdish civilians, including Aram Khaledi-Nasab, were imprisoned for their involvement in the 2022 "Women, Life, Freedom" protests in Iran. They were initially arrested in September 2022 and detained at the Ministry of Intelligence facility. ([kurdistanhumanrights.org](https://kurdistanhumanrights.org/en/tag/aram-khaledi-nasab?utm_source=openai))

2. **Malek Ali Fadaie-Nasab**: In July 2023, the Supreme Court of Iran upheld the death sentences of Malek Ali Fadaie-Nasab and five others on charges of "armed rebellion." These individuals were detained in 2015 and faced retrials in 2023. ([en-hrana.org](https://www.en-hrana.org/tag/malek-ali-fadaie-nasab/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, there is a record of a legal case involving individuals with the surname "Khaledi":

3. **KHALEDI v. GLOBAL TRADING LTD HAR (2003)**: This case, decided by the Court of Appeals of Texas in 2003, involved a business dispute among brothers with the surname Khaledi. The case centered on a temporary injunction order against one of the brothers, Heydar "Shaun" Khaledi, related to business dealings and agreements. ([caselaw.findlaw.com](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/court/tx-court-of-appeals/1109873.html?utm_source=openai))

These instances involve individuals with similar names but do not pertain to a person named "Ali Khaledi Nasab."

citations.title: Aram Khaledi-Nasab Archives - KHRN | Kurdistan Human Rights Network
KHALEDI v. GLOBAL TRADING LTD HAR (2003) | FindLaw
